meaning: A tenuous connection between an old discussion topic and a new one.
(Of an object) very old, old-fashioned
To leave immediately. Pull off.
To ask someone to leave immediately, "Get out/off!/Buzz off! /Take a hike!".
Without money, broke, to owe money
To speak provocatively to someone.
Don't worry. We'll make through this (in a distress/stressful situation)
Something happened or was over very quickly.
Person is not too bright / has mental issues
Person is not too bright / has mental issues
Not to be in an immediate hurry.
Not to abstain from food or drink (always used with a negative).
Not to abstain from alcohol (always used with a negative).
Inexperienced, gullible (usually used with a negative, "nobody's fool")
To stick to details, failing to see from a wider perspective
To live without cleaning up after oneself, or bothering about what others think about one.

A statement that a desired object simply isn't available, no matter how much someone keeps asking for it. The word "siksi" (into that) is substituted with the object in question, in translative "-ksi".
With little or no effort required.
To die or to give up.
To die.
To throw away. (As in throwing into a lake.)
A euphemism for "your fly is open".
to have it under control or to be able to do the task at hand (to not have it under control or not being able to do the task at hand)
Shocked, mouth agape, utterly unprepared, never heard
Away, to an unknown place, never to be seen again. While the name Nevada is an obvious reference to the U.S. state, "huitsin" probably refers to Hiisi.
To smile very broadly and happily.
To act alarmedly; to panic.
Willingly or by force.
At a place popular or populated enough to earn one's respect. Can also be used more literally, to mean at a place where one can be rescued.
Goes very, very easily.
insistently.
Something is finally succeeding and one can proceed.
If you favour one, you'll discriminate the others.

idiom: joko teet tai itket ja teet
meaning: A direct order to do something, whether the addressed wants to do it or not. The word "teet" ('you do') can be substituted with whatever verb is necessary from context.
When someone buttons up his/her shirt wrong.
Possibly a calque from the English phrase "a godforsaken place". Sometimes implies a disrespect of rural communities.
To be in a great hurry
Haphazardly implemented.
Being clueless about something or understanding the point slowly.
To live within the law (possible Biblical metaphor).
Two sides of a thing, cf. "two sides of a coin"
Downhearted
To have unresolved disputes, cf. English "bone to pick"
To go to waste.
To take a far too long time, or be of far too much effort.
Calque from English — natively korvessa Cf. English "In the middle of bumfuck Egypt"
To constantly and obviously covet something without actually making a move to get it, or to try to approach a difficult topic of speech in a roundabout way.
Difficult to obtain
An implication that there's something foul behind the scenes, the situation is not what it appears to be.

idiom: konstit on monet (, sanoi akka, kun kissalla pöytää pyyhki)
meaning: There's more than one way to do something. Often used when it becomes necessary to resort to unconventional methods. (cf. "there is more than one way to skin a cat.")
To finally get around to leaving.
A place that is somewhere in an area with no interesting things surrounding it, to be "out in the sticks".
Left by oneself, without outside support.
Acting excessively posh and snobby. Usually an implication of misplacen superiority towards others.
Two people or things that seem extremely alike; two peas in a pod.
Perfectly well in its own right; for example "a woman without a husband is like a fish without a bicycle".

idiom: kuin lasta löisi / helppoa kuin lapsen lyöminen/hakkaaminen
meaning: Very, very easy.
Being extremely cranky.
Standing unnaturally or needlessly upright. To be turgid and bumptious. To be seemingly nervous.
Sulky or (easily) irritated
Extremely slow, difficult, or arduous.
(To sink) without a trace.
Extremely slow
Very calm.

idiom: Kuka kissan hännän nostaa ellei kissa itse?
meaning: To toot your own horn or boast about yourself.
Boasting of oneself with cheap merits, being "king of the hill" when said hill is for example a garbage pile. It is easy as no one else wants to be the king of a garbage hill.
Extremely happy & satisfied
Old Finnish swearing if it's really cold outside. Like in English: it's cold as hell!
To do an about-face/turnabout.
give up
An unsuccessful, futile or abortive effort.
To live outside the law (possible Biblical metaphor).
Expressing doubt, skepticism.
A slow-witted or mentally handicapped person

To deliberately look for loopholes, in order to follow the letter without following the spirit. Note: Based on the Bible (Luke 4:1-13, Matthew 4:1-11 and Psalms 91:11-12). English equivalent: The devil can cite scripture for his purpose. (Shakespeare, The Merchant of Venice act 1, scene 3)
To leave without cleaning up after oneself. (holli from Swedish hålla (to keep) + tupa).
To leave extremely fast (also used when an inanimate object is quickly propelled to a great speed)
To leave quickly
To go out of control.
To make statements without requisite knowledge. Often used of one's own words Cf. English "I may be speaking out of my ass"
to cost very much, to be very expensive.
to pay very much, leaving oneself with very little money left over.

idiom: Manu on työnsä tehnyt, Manu saa mennä
meaning: An ironic expression, when faced with ingratitude after doing a favor. The name "manu" comes from the word for "master", like shoemaker-master. In old times these professionals used to tour the countryside practicing their profession.

Gaining something good without any effort - just turning up and getting paid. The name "manu" comes from the word for "master", like shoemaker-master. In old times these professionals used to tour the countryside practicing their profession, and the pay was often a meal.

Broke (without money). The Persian for "dead" is "mat". In Finnish it is pronounced as "matti" as in "Shakki Matti" (Shah Mat). "Minulla on matti kukkarossa" could be translated "My moneypurse is dead". In a similar way "Olen täysin matti" means "I am dead tired".
Not relevant anymore, often used of past offenses or sorrows, similar in tone to English "let bygones be bygones".
To be misguided, to go wrong; usually used to describe unintended consequences of decisions or plans
Something goes completely wrong. Could be translated as "Shatters as gingerbread".
To succeed, to work as planned.
To be too difficult for one to comprehend.
To meditate on the mysteries of the world; used ironically, to do nothing (from Finnish mythology).
To not pay attention to what's going on.
Ideas or other actions start to get out of control.
to be (possessively) jealous of someone (a person)
(To throw) away.
Of a wide-smile face.

This idiom has been misheard as "nalli kalliolla" (explosive primer on rock). The original idiom is "Jäi kuin alli kalliolle", meaning "Was left behind, like long-tailed duck". When migratory birds are leaving in autumn, the long-tailed ducks leaves later than other birds.
Sobering up, as in the sense of not drinking alcoholic beverages for a week or a month.
To be very grumpy first thing in the morning when everything seems to go wrong. Similar to English "get up on the wrong side of the bed".
To show someone how to properly do a thing they are attempting to do.
To show that one can do something better than the person the "eggs" are to be shown to, OR, to give somebody a good beating.
To wait for something very anxiously, to the point of desperation.
To die.
out of the frying pan into the fire, from one bad situation to another
used to describe almost anything (mostly anger) in excessive quantity. also used in conjunction with the subject of immediate action
Being lost, missing, in despair, perished.
a person who is like a lamb does nothing alone. the person does everything that for example the clique he/she belongs to.

idiom: olla pää sitä varten, ettei selkäranka valu housuihin
meaning: To be helplessly stupid.
Something should be corrected, possibly with quite harsh means.
Having a personal interest or investment in the matter.
Learn a lesson the hard way
Learn a lesson the hard way
To take a chance when an opportunity strikes.
To encounter severe problems.
To perform even the most minimal effort. Cf. English "lift a finger". Nearly always used with a negative.
Used to claim that a person is guilty of the very thing of which they accuse another. Cf. English "pot calling kettle black".
Without money, broke.
To do something in a needlessly complicated way, failing to see an easier way
to be really drunk
Very bad at doing something, usually manual labour. Cf. English "All Thumbs".
Pregnant. Cf. English "with child"
(To disappear) without a trace Cf. English "like a fart in the wind"
Having a crush on someone
A huge (often excessive) amount of something.
to get shamed because you’ve lost to someone or been proved wrong
To start to object to something. Often used if that something has already been generally agreed on.
More than asked for, generously. The Porvoo measure was a standardized measuring cup used by tax men to measure grain.
To die. Cf. English "to kick the bucket"
To leave a task to someone with a conflict of interest.
A person who insists on being sharply and formally dressed, but who appears to do little, if any, actual work. Almost always used of men, but sometimes of women too.
Confusing two unrelated things, either for each other, or as relating to each other. Cf. comparing apples and oranges.
Completely wrong.
As the bad exception in an otherwise good company. More commonly used in a positive way, c.f. "every little bit helps".
Physically strong.

Caught straight from doing a no-good thing, such as stealing fish from your neighbour's trap. Cf. English "caught red-handed". E.g. the American TV program "Cheaters" is translated to "Rysän päältä" in Finnish.
Used as a reply when someone says they are or do something, meaning "so am I" or "so do I". "Rahikainen" refers to the speaker, regardless of what their actual surname is.
Raining heavily. Raining cats and dogs.

"To put off/execute". Due to fire hazard, saunas were built at a distance from the house, and what was or happened behind the sauna was out of sight, "behind the backyard". Normally, there was a "tunkio" or a garbage pile behind the sauna, and when e.g. a sick or injured horse or dog  needed to be put down, it was taken behind the sauna for the job.
To boast, or to speak provocatively.
To be unprepared, whether it is a task at hand or one is going somewhere without thinking what is needed to take along.
As a final bonus, benefit or gift
Approaching a demanding task unprepared and with careless attitude
At an indeterminate point in the future, possibly never. "Tuohikuu" is a fictional month but sounds like the rural-oriented Finnish names for the 12 months.
Same as above.

There is going to be a fight. Finnish fighting knife, "Helapääpuukko" (Puukko with bone-breaking ferrules) is carried in hardened leather scabbard, and the scabbard mouth has water-tight fit. Before knife-fight starts, fighters need to twist the knife handle to loosen it for quick-drawing. When knife is twisted within scabbard, the blade clatters against the hardened leather, and makes clattering sound.
To enter uninvited.
Not doing anything, with an implication that one should be doing something.
To dislike. Implies vindictiveness. Often juxtaposed with the antonym.
Excessively full, nothing will fit in any more. Comes from the Great Northern War, where a Finnish soldier called Turunen had stuffed his gun so full of food he couldn't shoot it any more.
Not to know anything about the a given thing and thus be stunned, or to say things that are not relevant to the thing.
Not yet ready or finished, with an implication of not knowing when it will be. Originally army slang.
To die.
A great number or amount, especially one that will stay great after partaken of.
There's no harm in having some extra resources or precautions
Someone in constant opposition and immune to any reasoning
To be provoked.
To sleep.
To execute by hanging. Almost always used of suicide.
To beat someone, especially punch in the face. The verb vetää is a verb with diverse, disparate meanings, used to indicate a sudden jerk or a single, quick movement.
Someone fainted
Very long time ago.
Very long time ago.
To explain with very simple terms.

idiom: yhdeksän hyvää ja kymmenen kaunista, yhdeksän hyvää ja kahdeksan kaunista
meaning: Lots of good-sounding promises, with an implication they are unlikely to be kept.
Good, but failed, attempt.
Not looking good at all. Comes from an allegation of being the son of a whore.
To be confused about something.
Also to be amazed of some mind-blowing knowledge/to be confused about something so you couldn't say anything out of your mouth.
Not having a clue, being useless.
